content.description: Thin crack up and over a bulge to a set of anchors. Recommended two rope rappel.
content.location: To the left of Big Bird Crack approx. twenty feet.

content.description: Some true stabbing to a crux pocketed bulge. Right of the big dihedral.
content.location: The bolt route up the center of the slab around the corner to the right of the main Big Bird Wall.

content.description: A short full-value canyon face climb. Cruxy down low, with the angle and difficulty diminishing with height. Great pocket-pulling!
content.location: Immediately right of Call Me a Cab, or the 3rd sport route right of Edwards Crack.

content.description: A tricky one-move-wonder crux down low followed by lots of great pocket pulling. Joins the upper flake of Call Me a Cab, so bring some gear.
content.location: The second bolted route right of Edwards Crack.

content.description: A wavy wide flake with great moderate climbing. Traverse at the top to the anchors on Going to Extremes.
content.protection: #1-#3 cams, maybe some larger hexes, chains.
content.location: About 10' right of Call Me a Cab. Scramble up onto a shelf to start it. Located behind the pine tree in the area's overview photo.

climbs.name: Edwards Crack
climbs.fa: Steve Edwards, Joe Feeley, Steve Cropley 1983.

content.description: The uber-classic canyon trad route! A splitter fingercrack up a yellow, right-facing dihedral capped by a roof. Ascend it using assorted stemming, laybacking, fingerlocks, and faceholds; save some energy for the devious traverse below the upper roof to the anchors.
content.protection: Doubles of medium stoppers BD #8-#10 work great, also some #.4-#.75 camalots or equivalent, and one larger #2 or #3 for the top.
content.location: On the left side of the wall. Obvious splitter yellow dihedral.

content.description: A great moderate on the right side of the wall.
content.protection: 7 bolts and some small gear for the horizontal between the 1st and 2nd bolts. Chains.
content.location: From where the trail meets the wall, cut right a short ways to a clean pocketed slab with a vegetated right-facing dihedral immediately left of it.

climbs.name: Close To The Edge
climbs.fa: FA: Mike Board, Clay Jenkins, Mick Pattinson, 1987

content.description:
Follow the bolt line on the face just right of the small roof on the Big Bird Wall.

A BEAUTIFUL route that demonstrates the quality and "flavor" of most of the canyon.  Pumpy start... a couple long pulls... SHARP pockets... and a SPECTACULAR view of Tongue River.
content.protection: Whoever bolted this route... EXCELLENT JOB!  Can't remember for sure... 8 to 10 quickdraws will lead you to a two-bolt chained anchor.

content.description: An intriguing shallow right-facing dihedral with a thin fingercrack in it. Great climbing and good stopper placements. The upper 1/2 is cruiser flake.
content.protection: Doubles of small to med. stoppers (BD #7-#10 work great), chains.
content.location: The obvious shallow right-facing dihedral/flake about 15' right of Edwards Crack.

content.description: Wide hand to fist crack which runs up to a huge roof. Route is 5.9 to the roof, mid to high 5.10 with the roof. The roof has a committing finish withe either a nasty heel hook or a tensiony, tough full-body slither up through the very edge of the crack.
content.protection: New anchors above the roof. Medium to large pro, large (fist-sized or larger) pro for the roof.
content.location: Route is around arete to the left of Edward's Crack, obvious crack.
